<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 186]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 165, 236]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 263]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 220, 722, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 182, 80, 223]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 220, 722, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 273, 80, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 279, 179, 294]]<|/det|> PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 302, 413, 318]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[785, 302, 905, 317]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 396, 372]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 401]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 225, 433]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 294, 451]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 761, 467]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 478, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 495, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 511, 363, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 325, 545]]<|/det|> - You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 579, 559]]<|/det|> - You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 588, 214, 603]]<|/det|> INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 30 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 618, 730, 637]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 Fig. 1.1 shows two identical cylindrical metal conductors \(P\) and \(Q\), each of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 118, 834, 311]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 331, 532, 348]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 363, 921, 379]]<|/det|>
The conductors are placed parallel to each other. The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of P to point X is \(p\). The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of Q to point X is \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 410, 918, 425]]<|/det|>
The two conductors are electrically connected in parallel. This parallel combination is connected in series to a power supply and a resistor. The potential difference \(V\) between the ends of \(P\) is the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 439, 581, 456]]<|/det|>
same as the potential difference between the ends of Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 470, 716, 487]]<|/det|>
The magnetic flux density at \(X\) due to the currents in the conductors is \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 567, 518]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(B\) is related to \(p\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 523, 573, 555]]<|/det|>
\[
B=\frac{Y A V}{L p}+\frac{Y Z A V}{L q}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 564, 363, 579]]<|/det|>
where \(Y\) and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 594, 693, 611]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(B\) and \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 624, 625, 641]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 655, 700, 672]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(Y\) and \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 687, 382, 703]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 718, 393, 735]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 749, 410, 764]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 778, 347, 793]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 810, 352, 826]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 841, 446, 858]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 581, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates the cooling of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 708, 123]]<|/det|>
The temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the laboratory is measured using a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 642, 152]]<|/det|>
Hot water is added to an insulated beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 165, 753, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 421, 532, 438]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 453, 918, 469]]<|/det|>
The thermometer measures the temperature of the water. At time \(t\) the temperature of the water is \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 500, 454, 516]]<|/det|>
A series of readings of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 531, 565, 547]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\theta\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[409, 560, 592, 583]]<|/det|>
\[
\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{R}}+\left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\frac{t}{k}\right)}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 597, 579, 614]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_{0}\) is the temperature at \(t=0\) and \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 626, 708, 645]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\ln \left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right)\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 657, 611, 674]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 841, 590, 892]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 482, 91]]<|/det|> (b) Values of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 105, 540, 120]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 135, 854, 446]]<|/det|>
\(t / \min\)
\(\theta /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
\(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
\(\ln \left(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\)
6.0

\(57.0 \pm 0.5\)

\(41.0 \pm 0.5\)

Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right)\) and \(\ln \left(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 534, 874, 553]]<|/det|> (c) (i) Plot a graph of \(\ln \left(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\) against \(t / \min\). Include error bars for \(\ln \left(\left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 918, 583]]<|/det|> (ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 918, 629]]<|/det|> (iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(iv) Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 228, 587, 245]]<|/det|>
\[y-intercept =\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 918, 278]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(K\) and \(\theta_{0}\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 456, 592, 512]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{gathered}
K= \\
\theta_{0}=
\end{gathered}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 536, 643, 555]]<|/det|>
(ii) Determine the absolute uncertainty in your value of \(\theta_{0}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[394, 688, 588, 709]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 722, 634, 739]]<|/det|>
